text: Needs citation
…needed?

I don’t think this is very important, certainly not as important as a deeper interpretation of your results. So you found that shelter decreases aggression, and now what does that mean for the fish, their fitness, and natural/artificial selection?
How is JH amount related to length? Explain why you think this
Why? Cite some studies.
Number your figures in the order to which you refer to them.

Again, this can all go in your methods. The independent and dependent variable are made clear already by saying that you will be testing the effects of Martins IGR.  I understand that you are just trying to state them explicitly, as the resource guide tells you to, but this is unnecessary.

Make sure you have some version of your hypothesis near the beginning of your abstract so that readers understand that you were testing something and not just running this experiment without any expected outcome.
What was the hypothesis? The hypothesis of the experiment should be included in the Abstract.

Good job referring people to your figure, but remember to number your figures in the order in which you present them in the paper (so the first figure referenced should be “Figure 1”, the second should be “Figure 2”, etc.)
it’s a little difficult to read this with all the colors being so different. Is it possible to get all treatment groups to be one color and all controls to be another?
Be more specific about what you mean here, what is the exact thing you are measuring?
It’s not their weight that makes them unable to move on, it’s the level of JH
Do not talk about stats like this in the discussion
Put the p-value here, not the alpha value
This should go before you mention the methods briefly
Also introduce statistical tests you performed to analyze the data
You can say this different. Once the threshold was determined, 3 myograms were recorded for each gastrocnemius muscle and the amplitude of contraction was measured.
Don’t use so much detail when explaining the behaviors; save that for the methods
In what pathway?
You can say it rejects the null hypothesis, but the way you have it phrased here is a little odd
Save this for the Table caption
This is confusing.
Don’t need to use quotations, just paraphrase the article
You should reference your figure in here.
Your methods need to explain your analysis methods and your results need to include statistics.
Put this into mL
You need to be more scientific with your language. Make sure you state means and SDs
That’s your reagent table
This is good info! But should have a citation.
Also, recall that you didn’t quantify the presence of chloroplasts in your samples. You could have done it using a hemocytometer.
Not bad justification for your hypothesis, but background on the fact that JH regulates growth/molting in these caterpillars would be better.

Typically, if more than two treatments are involved (in this case, you used 3 including the control), an ANOVA would be used. But since there were just 3, I’ll let this go. Do let me know, however, if you’d like to learn more about ANOVA in case you need to know it in the future
Specify the volumes used
You should explain (probably in the results) why experiment 4 has incomplete data. You need a lot of justification to exclude ¼ of all your data points as outliers.
Be specific. Will the treatment caterpillars weigh less? More?
Outside sources missing (Basic criteria)
You don’t want to get those results by hope
Include a sentence about your results and one about your conclusions.
elaborate a little more on this concept to indicate implications of your experimental design at a broader context
This is ambiguous, based on previous knowledge, you can make a prediction.
Plagiarized
Error bars represent…
supports
Use proper citation format
Why? Do you think this is affecting your result? How? Do not include this if you are not sure that those were limitations of your experiment
Refer to figures. Include your t-test results to justify.
25mM (This is a concentration for concentration. 25mM = 25mmol/L)
How many tails? Instead of your last sentence here, you can just say that you determined significance at the p=0.05 level. “How far off” is not a particularly scientific or informative term.
It is a large cell! (Why it’s so cool!)
Good, explain the commitment pulse a little more and use the hormone imbalance point a little more.
So how does this relate to what you are doing, since you are not looking at pupation?

2% water agar

Write this section in past tense. Also use the actual symbols instead of writing out words like “degrees Celsius” or “microliters”
The electrodes were not recording the myograms. Those were stimulation electrodes. To record the myograms, a force transducer was used.

No need to explain what the t-test does, but also this is not quite right. A t-test might find no significant difference (as in this case), so the groups are not always statistically significantly different.
I would highlight on the fact that A23187 targets both IP3 and Ca2+ activated intracellular channels. If 2-APB targets IP3, think about how you could improve your current experimental design.

Pretend you are writing a scientific journal article. Avoid phrases like, “in this lab.” You could instead open by explaining what resource allocation is and why root:shoot ratio is a good measure for it.
These graphs shouldn’t have titles
remove (Methods details 2)
I think you are talking about twitch threshold? I would call it such throughout your paper so it makes more sense
Give more detail about these other experiments
Make sure you include the specific means and standard deviations
Since stats weren’t significant, you can’t say there’s a difference. Even if means are slightly different
I don’t understand this statistical outcome. What did they compare? That is not clear. Do not use sentences for the statistical analysis only. Ths should be supporting the actual result.

Another potential reason could be error in isolating the chloroplasts from the leaves. Recall that you didn’t actually record the relative density of chloroplast this time. Going through that step to ensure your sample actually had a high density of chloroplast would be an effective way to ensuring that you had chloroplast in your treatment to begin with.
This should go earlier in the discussion.

Check your axesx-axis: there were not control frogs. The same muscle was used for both conditions, control and treatment. Write the axis in correspondence to that. Can you be more specific for the y-axis? Amplitude of contraction

If you mention this, you’re going to have to actually talk about the experiment they did

Why did the contractions were weaker? You can talk about the way you measured the amplitude. Using that measuring method, the amplitude were smaller, however the muscle contraction was continuous, no relaxation.

this needs to be backed up by result data

Comparison should be between groups and not between replicates
Be careful about your sources. Generally for scientific uses, you want to cite scholarly sources (Scientific articles or .edu/.gov)

Methods – not in introduction
Redundant
Use this as an example of a figure legend. In each figure you can average the information from the 3 frog legs, not just 1
A myogram is a representation of the temporal curse of a contraction. It is not something that you use to record the data.
Be more specific about the differences. That way, your p-values make more sense.

Need to fix the position of the error bars, as well as make sure they represent the correct values.  You will need to calculate the standard deviation for all 16 of these averages, and input those values as “custom” error bars for each bar.
No need to include the null hypothesis

conducted
How did you keep the leg stable? Specify that it was pinned to the dissecting tray.

Fish are ectothermic, so they do not regulate their body temperature. Hence, they do not exert energy towards maintaining homeostasis. Explain your data in terms of the metabolic inefficiencies of bettas in colder water.
…what is going on with this graph? Where’s the y-axis? Why do the numbers have so many digits? Why are the bars the same for both groups?

What does this number provide you information wise? It is strange that the standard deviation is almost 10 times as large as the average. Maybe rethink how you report this if at all
Although you accepted your null hypothesis, there was a significant result for chickweed exposed to 640 nm at 30 min. It would be worthwhile to note it here.
This is not primary, peer-reviewed literature. See me if you need help with finding literature

This information is not very relevant for the experiment, so you can omit it in the Abstract. The Abstract is the summary of your paper and it has a limit for the number of words, so you want to include just the most relevant information.Instead, consider the idea of mentioning the hormonal control of growth in this insect.
Cite your figures
Why? You need to introduce the mechanism of aggression in order for your reader to understand your hypothesis.
You can’t have standard deviations on just one value. Check this graph and it’s values
Adapt really isn’t the right word here; it refers to a specific evolutionary process as opposed to the plasticity of a trait
If these are just single values than you shouldn’t have standard deviations with them
Similarly, do not try to interpret or discuss your data just yet.
You can cite your own figures in this section.
What does Precor mimic?
Good real-world connection. Try to look for other sources aside from Munns, I think there is some good research out there on salinization of farmlands and how that might affect crop yields.
You already did this and are just writing it up now.
The threshold would be the minimum voltage required by the stimulator to produce contraction in the muscle. I don’t’ think you found any maximums.
This is raw data

What cell functions do light fulfill? An unfamiliar reader needs more background about light and its role in resource allocation in order to make sense of your hypothesis
Not really, careful here. Your hypothesis was not supported because your stats say there wasn’t a significant difference in their change in weight
Axis labels are really small. Try enlarging them to make reading the graph easier. Also try to have a legend with colors rather than words.

Report means and SDs together; it’s hard to pair means and SDs when they’re separated by a sentence or two.

Amperes is current Voltage is the Amplitude of the shock administered to the leg.  You are confusing the word Amplitude (which is how tall the stimulus is on a graph = volts) with Amperes (the flow rate of the current in the wire = amps).

error bars are the same for all the data points. This is not quite right. Check the excel tutorial to learn how to add the error bars (Sakai/ BioCore Guide/ Displaying data/ Graphs)
This is a lab report, it should be written in past tenses using active or passive voices.
Condense to the points that are most relevant

No need to include specific quantities in the intro. You can save it for the methods.

Citation formatting. Check the BioCore Guide pages 48-49

Why paired? I’m not sure that makes sense here. Please let me know and ask if you have any questions!
No citations in the abstract. If it’s specific enough to need a citation, that’s too much detail for the abstract.

Try to summarize your methods in a better way without putting too much detail. For example, all the procedure to isolate 200 ul into microtubes with labels A, B, B pellet, and C can be condensed in a single line stating that the sample containing the pellet after second centrifuge was used. Because if you followed the protocol properly to isolate the chloroplast, you should have the highest chloroplast in your B pellet sample.At the end of your Methods section, indicate what kind of statistical test you perform to analyze your data. Just state a straight forward sentence stating that the statistical test x was conducted to analyze the data of the control and treatment groups.
Refer to figure again.Report the results of your ANOVA properly (see resource guide) – need the p-value in the results section.
This is a lot of graphs. I would include only the bar graphs, as the line graphs are not super necessary and don’t add a whole lot to your paper
For all the results that were not significant, pick the ones that caught your attention and only include those.

I would go ahead and include means +/- SDs in this section. Also, what are your other p-values? Typically, an ANOVA gives you one p-value for overall variance, and then you interrogate individual groups with the Tukey-Kramer, which, for your conditions, should give you more than one p-value.
Why is shelter a relevant stimulus? You need to elaborate so that your reader understands the underlying logic of your hypothesis
Significant difference?

Title should VERY briefly state the main takeaway of your experiment
I think you mean groups (each interaction of fish is a trial in this situation)
Methods should not be a list and you do not need to provide a list of materials. You need far more detail.

Report the statistical outcome with the main observation, not in a separate sentence. Remember the example from lab last week.

Some comments I only marked once. For example, when I said to use the actual word “percentage” instead of the symbol “%,” be sure to apply it to the whole report.
The x-axis doesn’t need that little 1 there and could use a better label, and the y-axis label needs units.
Remember, start your abstract broadly. You need a sentence or two of background before you state the purpose of the experiment.
You graph needs to have 2 columns, showing the average of the pot averages. Also needs to have error bars. See me for help with making graphs.

Some problems with interpretation here. Yes, your p value was close to 0.05, but it was higher than 0.05 which means there’s not a significant difference. Stick with a “black and white” interpretation of statistics
Not quite sure about this suggestion. The animal is sensitive to the JH levels during its entire life.
I would just say you are testing this in the gastrocnemius muscle of Rana pipiens, the Northern Leopard Frog
This is considered as interpretation which should not be in this section. Basic Criteria error#2

Make sure to include an actual description of any figures. Only tables (Should be labeled as “table 1, table 2 separately from figures) do not need descriptions.

The abstract should have at least one sentence wih background information. Something like an introduction to the topic.

Put this in terms of R:S ratio differences between the two groups. All this tells me right now is that you predict the R:S ratio for shade plants will be < 1, which is not what you tested. Once you have rephrased your hypothesis, make sure you also correct this in the discussion.

Avoid this recipe style of writing methods section because that’s not how it is used in a scientific literature. Check primary literature on similar experiments to see how they wrote their methods section and revise.

This abstract is a bit too much methods. Try rewriting it with two sentences about your intro, state your hypothesis, one methods sentence, your results and whether your hypothesis was supported, and your conclusion

All of this should be moved it does flow well with the next sentence/paragraph

If your results do not support the hypothesis, it doesn’t mean that you did it wrong. Don’t assume that you have errors. Only mention the errors if oyu are sure that they were there and they are really affecting the result.
Avoid using questions unless it is a research question nested under your hypothesis

You seemed to have found the standard deviation between the 3 different stimulus voltages rather than among the amplitudes you averaged to receive your value at each stimulus voltages. (Ex. Not quite. It shares similar signal transduction mechanisms, but it’s multinucleate, unicellular organism.

The corpus cardiacum is a neurohemal organ, so it doesn’t secrete hormones. The brain hormone, according to its name, is produced in the brain by neurosecretory cells.

When reporting the results of a two-sample t-test, you need to include the resulting t-statistic, the degrees of freedom (df), and the corresponding P-value. Your statement might look like this, “The mean of the control group was not statistically significantly different than that of the experimental group (t-stat = 0.57, df = 26, P = 0.574).”

When reporting the results of a two-sample t-test, you need to include the resulting t-statistic, the degrees of freedom (df), and the corresponding P-value. Your statement might look like this, “The mean of the control group was not statistically significantly different than that of the experimental group (t-stat = 0.57, df = 26, P = 0.574).”

When reporting the results of a two-sample t-test, you need to include the resulting t-statistic, the degrees of freedom (df), and the corresponding P-value. Your statement might look like this, “The mean of the control group was not statistically significantly different than that of the experimental group (t-stat = 0.57, df = 26, P = 0.574).”

Not true. Getting an insignificant p-value does NOT mean that you did the experiment wrong. If the p-value is very insignificant (0.9, for example), then there is simply no measurable effect from the treatment you used, but that is a result, not a sign that the experiment was wrong. If the p-value is close to significant (like yours), that means that while the results are not statistically significant, you did see a biologically significant result and your hypothesis might have been supported.

When reporting the results of a two-sample t-test, you need to include the resulting t-statistic, the degrees of freedom (df), and the corresponding P-value. Your statement might look like this, “The mean of the control group was not statistically significantly different than that of the experimental group (t-stat = 0.57, df = 26, P = 0.574).”

IMPORTANT: your null hypothesis is that varying salt concentration would not significantly affect the photosynthesis, which you found in your experiment. So, you accept the null hypothesis. When reporting the results of a two-sample t-test, you need to include the resulting t-statistic, the degrees of freedom (df), and the corresponding P-value. Your statement might look like this, “The mean of the control group was not statistically significantly different than that of the experimental group (t-stat = 0.57, df = 26, P = 0.574).”

This is not quite right.  The stats tells you that the trend that your eyes see in the data, simply the numbers,  is either strong or weak. However, if the data is weak (p>0.05) then you lose the opportunity to argue why this data was seen (biological processes)

You have your inference about the stats backwards. When p > 0.05, this means that your difference just happened by chance (no effect of your treatment). When p<0.05, this means that there was a signficiant effect of your treatment.

When reporting the results of a two-sample t-test, you need to include the resulting t-statistic, the degrees of freedom (df), and the corresponding P-value. Your statement might look like this, “The mean of the control group was not statistically significantly different than that of the experimental group (t-stat = 0.57, df = 26, P = 0.574).”

This is a simplified way of seeing this process. The membrane potential is the result of the efflux of K+ ions and the small influx of Na+ ions, through the leak channels. The movement of this ions is passive and it is determined by the electrochemical gradients. Having more K+ inside the cell creates the chemical gradient for this ion, which facilitates the outflux of this ion. The outflux of positive charges causes the negative potential

Technically you should only choose one type of statistical test: t-test or ANOVA. But I can argue for using both. So in this case, you can use an ANOVA, then if there is a significant p-value, look at which groups are significant from each other, then only run a t-test for those groups so you can get a p-value for those.
